comment.author: 10621515@N05
comment._content: that's more like camping than housing...

comment.author: 99002941@N08
comment._content: If I recall correctly wasn't this taken by Derry photographer Alexander Ayton in 1867?

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/99002941@N08] We don't have a photographer for this one, but I'd doubt it was as early as 1867. It's part of our Congested Districts Board collection, and that Board wasn't established until 1891.
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 99002941@N08
comment._content: The exact same photo appeared in an 1890s guide, 'Sights and Scenes of Ireland' where it was attributed to Alexander Ayton (along with several others), some of which are dated 1867-70. Also W.A. Maguire's 'A century in Focus' gives the photographer of this as Ayton.

comment.author: 99002941@N08
comment._content:
A closer examination of the photo shows the latter part of Ayton's mark (Londonderry) in the bottom right corner. 
I have a suspicion that when photos were presented by the C.D.B. to the Queen in 1900 (the presentation which led to Robert Welch being commended a given a Royal Warrent) that the Board used Ayton's photo which had been used, along with several others of Donegal, in the 1897 "Sights and Scenes of Ireland". Ayton died in 1900. In addition, according to Welch's Excursion Diary he only visited the Island once, July 1910.
